case_vignette:
A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of yellowish discoloration of the skin for 1 day. The discoloration first appeared on his face and then spread to his trunk. There have been no changes in his bowel habits or urination. He was born at 38 weeks’ gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. He is exclusively breastfed every 2–3 hours. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice of the face, chest, and abdomen. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 17.6 g/dL
Reticulocytes 0.3%
Maternal blood group A, Rh-negative
Fetal blood group 0, Rh-positive
Serum
Bilirubin, total 7 mg/dL
Direct 0.6 mg/dL
Free T4 7 μg/dL
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My baby's skin has turned yellowish, and it started on his face before spreading to his chest and belly.
How old is your baby?
He's 5 days old.
Is your baby feeding well and having frequent wet diapers?
He is breastfed every 2–3 hours and there have been no changes in his urination.
Has your baby experienced any fever, lethargy, or high-pitched crying?
No, there have been no such changes.
Was your baby born at term, and was the delivery normal?
Yes, he was born at 38 weeks and the delivery was uncomplicated.
Has your baby had any previous medical treatments or complications since birth?
No, he hasn't had any medical treatments or complications.
Do you or the baby's father have a history of jaundice as a newborn?
I don't know about the baby's father, but I personally don't have a history of jaundice as a newborn.
Final Diagnosis: Neonatal jaundice, likely physiological jaundice of the newborn.
